thread.title: Swedish ice skaters save a moose trapped in a frozen lake | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Swedish ice skaters save a moose trapped in a frozen lake | Daily Mail Online

author: Naomi Leach For Mailonline
title: Swedish ice skaters save a moose trapped in a frozen lake | Daily Mail Online
text: Share 161 shares The pair skate closer to the shallow edge of the lake where the moose is stuck, placing their own lives in danger with each step they take. The distressed animal has its head and front legs out of the water while its hind legs appear to be stuck. In a bid to save the exhausted animal, they work tirelessly for 30 minutes, chopping through a thick layer of ice with an axe to cut the creature a path to freedom The distressed animal has its head and front legs out of the water while its hind legs appear to be stuck It violently splashes water around but cannot lift itself any further out of the water. Mr Johannessen and Ms Sjosteen are filmed hammering at the ice with an axe and a third skater is also caught on camera helping. But suddenly, the trapped creature stops moving. The white ice has been peeled away and the slick black water of the lake is finally visible But the animal is too exhausted and cold to move and so the skaters must coax it out of the water Acknowledging it must be tired they prepare themselves to chop even more ice so that the moose has a clear path out of the water to the shore. Around 30 minutes later, the white ice has been peeled away and the slick black water of the lake is finally visible. But the animal is too exhausted and cold to move. The daredevil skaters plead with the animal to make a break for freedom after carving out a path for it Eventually the wild animal appears revived and dashes out of the icy water The heroic skaters coax the creature out of the water, pleading with it to make a break for freedom. Eventually it appears revived and dashes out of the icy water. After stretching its hind legs, the moose climbs through some shrubbery and disappears from view. The video has attracted over 400,000 views and has drawn praise from impressed animal lovers. One commentator, Achilleze, said: 'This is why humans were put on the planet. We all need to be earthkeepers' After stretching its hind legs, the moose climbs through some shrubbery and disappears from view Shared last week, the heart-warming YouTube video has attracted over 400,000 views. It's also drawn praise from impressed animal lovers. One commentator, Achilleze, said: 'This is why humans were put on the planet. We all need to be earthkeepers.'
